title: Africa: President Sirleaf Urges Increased American Investments in Africa
text:
President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf has urged American investors to see Africans as faithful partners and challenged them to increase their investments on the continent; either by working with governments, individuals or the private sector. 
She said Africa needs partnership that will propel its economy towards the next millennium 
According to a dispatch from New York, the Liberian leader made the call at the African Heads of State and Governments Investment Working Lunch organized under the auspices of the "Africa Investor" held at the Thomas Reuters Hall in Broadway, New York. 
She said Liberia and most African countries are endowed with natural resources but that due to infrastructural deficit, such countries will need partnership that will help accelerate their growth and development. 
President Sirleaf referred to the Sustainable Development Goals as essential tools for the realization of African Development as it clearly takes into account the needs of the developing countries. "For the first time the private sector and the civil society have played a key role in developing a roadmap for sustainable development." 
In particular, the President said financing for Development made the Agenda very inclusive process. 
Also speaking, President Museveni of Uganda said in order to advance economic prosperity in Africa, the continent will need two key players, the producers and the buyers. He observed that the private sector will therefore play a key role in stimulating the economy through patronizing the producer. adding, the producer and the consumer must be linked by the same level of passion. 
Sparking further, President Yoweri Museveni said that Africa was in search of entrepreneurs who use the spectacle to see opportunities and are ready to invest in them. 
Also speaking at the forum, President Peter Mutharika of Malawi said poor infrastructural development accounts for low key private investment in most African countries including his country. 
He indicated that his administration has therefore taken several steps to create a conducive environment for private sector investment, and urged investors to come to Malawi. 
Meanwhile, the Prime Minister of Ethiopia, Hailemariam Desalegm has urged the global media to avoid stereotyping by presenting gloomy pictures of affairs in Africa. He said in fact Africa was moving steadily in its quest for democratization and that the continent was handling its peace process with commitment. "Africa is rising up and this is our time," he concluded. Liberia
